meanings.definition: To move sideways in a shy or sneaky manner.
meanings.sent1: The cat would sidle along the wall, trying to go unnoticed.
meanings.sent2: She decided to sidle up to the door to eavesdrop on the conversation.
meanings.sent3: The spy attempted to sidle past the guards, but his noisy shoes gave him away.
meanings.sent4: The shadows seemed to sidle across the room as the sun set.
meanings.sent5: The ghostly figure appeared to sidle through the mist, sending shivers down my spine.

meanings.sent1: He would sidle closer to the table, hoping to catch a glimpse of the secret document.
meanings.sent2: The thief tried to sidle out of the room without being noticed.
meanings.sent3: The raccoon would sidle up to the trash can, looking for a late-night snack.
meanings.sent4: The snake seemed to sidle through the grass, almost invisible to the unsuspecting prey.
meanings.sent5: The mysterious figure continued to sidle along the dark alley, disappearing into the night.

meanings.definition: To walk in a timid or unobtrusive manner.
meanings.sent1: She would sidle into the room, trying not to attract attention.
meanings.sent2: The child would sidle up to the teacher, too shy to ask a question.
meanings.sent3: The penguin tried to sidle away from the group, feeling out of place.
meanings.sent4: The old man would sidle down the street, lost in his thoughts.
meanings.sent5: The deer seemed to sidle through the forest, graceful and silent.
